context: Ibn Sina's first appointment was that of physician to <a0_0><b10_0>the <b5_0><b6_0>emir, Nuh II<b10_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>, who owed him his recovery from a dangerous illness (<a4_0><b14_0>997<b14_0/><a4_0/>). Ibn Sina's chief reward for this service was <a1_0><b11_0>access to <b7_0>the royal library of the Samanids<b11_0/><b7_0/><a1_0/>, well-known patrons of scholarship and scholars. When the library was destroyed by fire not long after, the enemies of Ibn Sina accused him of burning it, <b8_0>in order for ever <a2_0><b12_0>to conceal the sources of his knowledge<b12_0/><b8_0/><a2_0/>. Meanwhile, he assisted <a3_0><b9_0><b13_0>his father<b13_0/><b9_0/><a3_0/> in his financial labors, but still found time to write some of his earliest works.
